It has been brought to my attention, that getting your tubes tied or burned is considered abortion.
 
 Why?
 
 Well, because you are preventing a human life.
 
 I, of course, don't agree.
 
 However, it has been made clear that it is preventing life by preventing the egg that might be fertilized from being fertilized. 
 
 I think that it is not fair. Say, perhaps, that the egg would never get fertilized? Then could I get my tubes tied? But, you will never know if the egg will ever produce into something more, until you die. So, should I not do what I want, based on something that I will never know?
 
 What do you think?

I have never heard that any form of pre-conception contraception were equaled to abortion.

 
 Unless of course you're Catholic. Any type of conception, while not considered "abortion" per se is still considered by the Catholic Church to be denying God's will and taking matters into your own hands... essentially playing God. 
 
 And I know somebody will have something to say about religion, but I please ask that anybody responding to this realize that I was only posting this information to let Iuris and others know that there are some who consider "pre-conception contraception" as not in line with the will of God according to their religion (specifically Catholicism in this case). It's not meant to spark a debate about religion, just factual information. 
 
 I personally don't hold these beliefs. 
 
 
Rather, I've heard it expressed that any sex that is not intended for procreation is sinful. A bit of difference.

 
 This is generally true with respect to Christian religions although you may still get some variance from one specific sect to another or even one specific church within a specific sect to another.

And Ryuuichi, a decision not to have children is something that a 17 year old is far from ready to make. The reversibility of the procedure is questionable. As for abortion, it is generally a one time effect and does not lead to permanent infertility (except perhaps as a rare unwanted side effect).

 
 I absolutely agree. Likewise, I don't think they're fully mature or ready in any sense of the word to make a decision on the life of an unborn child either. This is a conundrum of the pro-choice supporters who don't believe a child needs to have their parents informed of their decision to abort or that the parents/guardians of these children even need to know anything about it before or afterwards.
